Dear Ms. Canales:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The staff mentioned that the youth attempted to take their life
between 3/22-3/27 2025 by placing a cord around their neck. The
staff found the youth who was turning purple, and LE was never
contacted.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on April 2, 2025,
and reported staff at the facility stated there are in house
procedures to follow for Youth A so law enforcement is not
called. Complainant stated a staff member reported staff get in
trouble when staff call 911.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B reported
Youth A does not follow the rules and often tries to harm herself.
Youth B described an incident where Youth A went into the
bathroom and tied a phone cord around her neck. Youth B stated
Staff 3 had to remove the cord from Youth A’s neck and Youth A
was taken to the hospital. Youth B reported she could not recall if
Youth A was on constant staff supervision during this incident or
not. Youth B stated she has heard staff talk about having to
contact upper management prior to calling 911 but reported staff
do not always follow that policy. Youth B stated Staff 6 called 911
when Youth A was in the middle of the road without contacting
upper management first.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on April
3, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor stated
she was not working the night Youth A wrapped the cord around
her neck. Supervisor reported staff are supposed to contact upper
management to get permission prior to calling law enforcement if it
is not an emergency. Supervisor described an emergency being a
youth going AWOL or a youth having a medical emergency.
Supervisor stated there have been times staff wanted to contact
law enforcement for a youth who is being verbally aggressive or
refusing to follow directions. Supervisor reported calling law
2

enforcement for those reasons would not be appropriate and the
staff would be told they could not contact law enforcement.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she
was not working the night Youth A wrapped the cord around her
neck. Staff 1 reported staff are supposed to call upper
management prior to calling law enforcement. Staff 1 denied
being told by anyone at the facility she could not contact law
enforcement. Staff 1 stated in a medical emergency she would
probably still call upper management first unless it was a true
emergency and 911 needed to be called immediately.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she
was not working the night Youth A wrapped the cord around her
neck. Staff 2 described being a fill-in staff to help sit with a youth
at the emergency room or if there were gaps in the schedule.
Staff 2 stated it used to be staff could call 911 then had to follow
up with upper management so upper management could notify
licensing. Staff 2 stated this may have changed but she was not
sure.
Staff 2 reported she was not aware of Youth A’s extensive self-
harming behavior until being interviewed today. Staff 2 stated the
lead worker provides updates when Staff 2 comes on shift and
Staff 2 reviews the constant supervision sheet. Staff 2 was asked
if she reviewed Youth A’s safety plan upon starting her shift for the
day, approximately four hours earlier. Staff 2 denied reviewing
Youth A's safety plan at the time of being interviewed.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 3 described
working the night Youth A placed a charging cord around Youth
A’s neck. Staff 3 reported Youth A was talking about going
AWOL, went into her bedroom closet, walked out of her bedroom
and stated she was going to the bathroom. Staff 3 stated she sat
outside the bathroom door talking with Youth A while Youth A was
behind the closed bathroom door. Staff 3 reported Youth A
stopped talking for a couple of minutes, so Staff 3 knocked on the
door. Staff 3 stated the bathroom door swung open and Staff 3
saw Youth A laying on the bathroom floor with the charging cord
wrapped around her neck. Staff 3 reported Youth A’s whole body,
face, and fingers were purple. Staff 3 described removing the
cord from Youth A’s neck and Youth A opened her eyes. Staff 3
stated Youth A did not say anything, she just looked around the
3

bathroom. Staff 3 reported she told Staff 5 to call 911 and Staff 3
called Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA). Staff 3 stated
Emergency Medical Services (EMS) and Michigan State Police
(MSP) arrived at the facility and Youth A was transported to the
hospital. Staff 3 denied Youth A being on constant supervision
during this incident. Staff 3 stated she was staying close to Youth
A because Youth A was talking about going AWOL.
Staff 3 stated staff always have to get approval to call 911 from
upper management. Staff 3 reported there was one time staff
wanted to call 911 but upper management told staff to offer coping
skills to Youth A instead of calling 911. Staff 3 described the
evening staff were told they could not call 911, Youth A had hit
Staff 4 with a cookie sheet, causing injury, and was hiding a
plastic knife in her bra. Staff 3 reported staff at the facility are to
contact the Community Mental Health (CMH) crisis line and have
an evaluation completed at the home for Youth A instead of Youth
A always going to the Emergency Room (ER). Staff 3 stated
Youth A views the ER as a vacation where she can watch TV and
get snacks.
Staff 3 reported she has heard Staff 6 be rude toward youth at the
facility. Staff 3 described hearing Staff 6 tell Youth D, “at the end
of the day, I get to leave here, and you’ll still be here.” Staff 3
stated Staff 6 made this comment about two weeks ago. Staff 3
denied telling upper management about the comment made by
Staff 6. Staff 3 stated she did tell Staff 5 and planned on telling
AFA today.
Youth D and Youth E refused to be interviewed by myself or
DHHS Worker on April 3, 2025. Two attempts to interview the
youth were made by DHHS Worker and I.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported he
was not working the night Youth A wrapped the cord around her
neck. Staff 4 stated staff can contact 911 when a youth goes
AWOL or for medical emergencies without first contacting upper
management. Staff 4 described the night Youth A hit him with a
cookie sheet, he did get an injury and was bleeding, but he did not
require medical attention or feel the need to contact law
enforcement. Staff 4 stated Youth A was having a rough night but
was de-escalated by staff.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth C reported
4

Staff 3 was sitting outside the bathroom door talking with Youth A
the night Youth A wrapped a cord around her neck. Youth C
stated Youth A stopped responding and when the door opened
Youth A was purple and not talking. Youth C described staff
called 911 and EMS along with MSP arrived and took Youth A to
the hospital. Youth C stated staff must contact upper
management before calling 911 but staff do not always follow the
policy. Youth C denied having any concerns with staff but stated
Youth A’s behaviors make Youth C feel unsafe at times.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth A described
getting a charging cord from her closet after staff opened her
closet door and placing the cord in her pocket. Youth A stated
she told staff she had to use the bathroom, went to the bathroom,
shut the door and wrapped the cord around her neck. Youth A
stated staff were talking to her the entire time she was in the
bathroom. Youth A reported when she “came to”, staff were
looking at her and talking but Youth A did not respond. Youth A
stated staff called 911 and Youth A was transported to the
hospital. Youth A was smiling and laughing while providing this
information to the DHHS Worker and myself.
Approximately four to five minutes into the interview Staff 3
knocked on the door looking for Youth A. Staff 3 opened the door
and told Youth A she needed to tell Staff 3 where she was going
at all times. Staff 3 was Youth A’s assigned staff at the time of the
interview. Youth A was on constant supervision at the time of the
interview.
Youth A described the night outside with Staff 6 when Youth A hit
Staff 6 with the fiberglass yardsticks, Staff 6 made statements to
Youth A causing Youth A to become more escalated. Youth A
stated she hit Staff 6 one time with the yardstick and Staff 6 called
911 and told them she was being assaulted and wanted to press
charges for assault. Youth A stated she told Staff 6, “you want to
see an assault” and began hitting Staff 6 again with the yardsticks.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 5 reported
staff can call 911 when a youth goes AWOL or if there is a
medical emergency without upper management’s permission.
Staff 5 said other times when youth are escalated, staff are to call
upper management to see how to proceed.
5

Staff 5 reported Staff 3 told her Staff 6 said something to Youth D
about getting to leave at the end of the day while Youth D will still
be here forever. Staff 5 denied ever hearing Staff 6 make this
type of comment to any youth. Staff 5 stated when she was
outside with Staff 6 and Youth A the night Youth A was hitting
Staff 6 with the fiberglass yardsticks, she felt Staff 6’s comments
may have escalated Youth A. Staff 5 reported when Staff 6 called
911 it was because Youth A was hitting her with the yardsticks, it
was prior to Youth A going into the road. Staff 5 stated Staff 6
was angry and said “she [Youth A] kept fucking hitting me.” Staff
5 reported Youth A heard this and appeared to become further
escalated and told Staff 6, “you want to see an assault, I’ll show
you.”
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 6 described
Youth A being upset and going outside to check the mail. Staff 6
stated she told Youth A she could not check the mail which
caused Youth A to further escalate. Staff 6 reported she did tell
Youth A she could possibly press charges if her behaviors did not
improve. Staff 6 stated she could not recall if she was swearing
during the incident.
Staff 6 denied ever saying anything to any youth about getting to
go home at the end of the day while they have to be at the house
forever. Staff 6 described having a private conversation with Staff
3 when all the youth were sleeping about the youth needing to feel
safe and making the house a safe environment because this was
their home. Staff 6 denied hearing any staff make comments to
any youth about getting to go home at the end of the shift.
Staff 6 reported staff have been told they cannot call 911 unless
they have approval from upper management, regardless of the
situation. Staff 6 stated she called 911 the night Youth A was
hitting her with the fiberglass yardsticks without approval from
upper management because she was being assaulted by Youth A.
Video Review:
Video footage of 2/03/25 from the incident of Youth A wrapping
the charging cord around her neck was reviewed. Youth A enters
the bathroom and closes the door. Staff 3 is seen sitting on the
floor outside the bathroom door. Approximately four minutes after
Youth A enters the bathroom Staff 3 stands up, moves through
two youth and pushes the bathroom door open. There are no
cameras in the bathroom and there is no sound on the video.
Youth A was not on constant supervision on this date.
6

Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report for Youth A dated 2/3/25 from Youth A
placing a cord around her neck. Report is consistent with
youth and staff interviews. Youth A was not on increased
supervision during this incident.
• New Hope Policy, Law Enforcement Contact. Policy states,
“Law enforcement agencies and resources shall not be
used to manage the behavior of youth in the program
unless the Facility Administrator or designee determines
that such assistance is justified based on the seriousness
of events or to address an immediate threat to the
program's safety and security. Staff training shall be
provided on contacting law enforcement prior to working
with youth. This policy is not intended to prevent, prohibit,
or override an employees' duty to immediately contact 911
in the event of an emergency situation. The policy listed
examples of when law enforcement would be contacted by
a member of leadership including bomb threat, arson,
felony drug possession, sexual assault, kidnapping, deadly
weapons on site, and staff on youth battery. The policy
listed examples of when law enforcement would not be
contacted including: staff being hit during a de-escalation
attempt if the contact was accidental and/or unintentional,
youth on staff battery that does not result in injury, youth on
youth altercation that does not result in serious injury and
can be addressed through programming, minor program
disturbances, minor program damage, and non-compliant
behavior that does not present significant safety and
security concerns.”
• Telephone contact note between DHHS Worker and
Trooper. Trooper stated there was a note on file, MSP
assisted on 2/03/25 for Youth A having a cord tied around
her neck and assisted with carrying Youth A down the
stairs on a stretcher.
• Youth A’s Suicide Risk Assessment from 1/27/25 and
2/05/25. Youth A was taken off constant supervision on
1/27/25 and placed back on constant supervision on
2/05/25 after Youth A wrapped the cord around her neck.
• New Hope Policy, Youth Supervision, Movement Checks.
Policy states, “Program staff shall be able to account for the
whereabouts of youth under their supervision at all times.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance for appropriately supervising
Youth A when Youth A wrapped a charging cord around her neck.
Per youth and staff interviews as well as information gathered
7

from DHHS Worker after talking with MSP, MSP was contacted
and assisted EMS after Youth A wrapped the cord around her
neck.
The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth A’s whereabouts
were unknown by the assigned constant supervision staff for
approximately four to five minutes on April 3rd, 2025 when her
interview took place.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was offered for the facility to call the non-
emergency number for incidents when law enforcement is needed
but not an emergency.
Technical Assistance was offered to review with staff when staff
are to call 911 and when staff are to call upper management prior
to calling 911. Per staff interviews there seemed to be some
confusion.
Technical Assistance was offered to review with staff the
importance of reading safety plans at the beginning of each shift
to have an understanding of the specific supervision needs of
youth on safety plans. This is due to having fill in staff that do not
work regularly and go long periods of time between shifts.
Technical Assistance was offered to review with staff appropriate
ways to communicate with youth and to recognize how staff
communicate with youth could escalate a situation.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 3/27/25, a youth was dragged out of the roadway by staff as
the youth was laying down in attempt to take their life. The youth
assaulted staff and law enforcement was contacted.
8

Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on April 2, 2025,
and reported they had no additional information
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B reported
she was outside with Youth A and Staff 6 when Youth A became
upset after being told she could not get the mail so she began
hitting Staff 6 with a fiberglass yardstick. Youth B stated she tried
to help calm Youth A, but Youth A continued to hit Staff 6. Youth
B described other youth as well as Staff 3 coming outside to assist
Staff 6. Youth B reported Youth A walked into the middle of the
road where cars were driving and refused to move. Youth B stated
Staff 3 and Staff 6 were talking with Youth A trying to convince
Youth A to get out of the road. Youth B described Staff 3 and
Staff 6 attempting to guide Youth A by Youth A’s elbow out of the
road, but Youth A refused to move and sat down in the middle of
the road. Youth B stated when Youth A sat down in the road
Youth B and Youth C dragged Youth A to the side of the road, out
of traffic. Youth B denied any staff asking them [Youth B and
Youth C] to drag Youth A out of the road. Youth B reported Staff 6
stated she did not think staff could pull Youth A out of the road
without getting into trouble. Youth B stated Michigan State Police
(MSP) arrived and transported Youth A to the hospital.
Youth D and Youth E refused to be interviewed by myself or
DHHS Worker on April 3, 2025. Two attempts to interview the
youth were made by DHHS Worker and I.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported
Youth A was angry because she could not have additional snacks
and went outside stating she was going to get the mail. Staff 3
stated Staff 6 tried to verbally redirect Youth A and offered Youth
A different coping skills. Staff 3 described being upstairs with
youth but watching from the window; Youth A hit Staff 6 multiple
times with fiberglass yardsticks. Staff 3 reported Staff 5 went
outside to assist Staff 6 and attempted to restrain Youth A for
hitting Staff 6 but was unsuccessful with the restraint. Staff 3
stated she went outside with youth following her to switch out Staff
5. Staff 3 reported Staff 5 went back in the house to watch the
youth inside while Staff 3 worked with Staff 6 to deescalate Youth
A. Staff 3 described Youth A walking toward the road so Staff 3
told Staff 6 to escort Youth A away from the road. Staff 3 reported
Youth A punched Staff 6 in the arm and stomach so Staff 3 went
to restrain Youth A and move Youth A away from the road. Staff 3
stated Youth A stopped walking and sat down in the road and
9

refused to move as traffic was coming toward them. Staff 3
reported Youth B and Youth C grabbed Youth A by her ankles and
arms and moved Youth A out of the road to the curb. Staff 3
denied Youth B and/or Youth C were asked to move Youth A to
the curb. Staff 3 reported MSP arrived and took over the situation.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth C described
Youth A being outside yelling and hitting Staff 6 multiple times with
a yardstick. Youth C stated Staff 5 tried to restrain Youth A, but
Youth A was able to get out of the restraint. Youth C reported
Staff 5 and Staff 6 tried to guide Youth A out of the road, but
Youth A sat down in the road. Youth C stated she ended up
grabbing Youth A’s arms and legs along with Youth B’s help and
dragged Youth A to the curb to get out of traffic. Youth C denied
any staff asking or telling her and/or Youth B to drag Youth A out
of the road. Youth C stated they [Youth B and Youth C] only
dragged Youth A to the curb because staff cannot pick up youth
because of the restraint rules. Youth C reported MSP arrived right
after and Youth A was taken to the hospital.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth A described
some staff allow her to check the mail and others do not allow her
to check the mail. Youth A described being upset because Staff 6
would not allow her to check the mail, so Youth A grabbed a
fiberglass yardstick and hit Staff 6 multiple times. Youth A
reported Staff 5 came outside and tried to place Youth A in a
restraint for hitting Staff 6, but Youth A got out of the restraint and
went into the road. Youth A stated Staff 5 and Staff 6 attempted
to guide Youth A out of the road by placing their hands on the
back of Youth A’s elbows. Youth A reported she was mad, did not
want to move so she sat down in the road. Youth A described
Youth B and Youth C pulling her out of the road. Youth A stated
MSP arrived and placed her in the police car because she tried to
jump in front of traffic.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 5 described
Youth A being upset, going outside and telling Staff 6 she was
going to check the mail. Staff 5 stated Staff 6 told Youth A no she
could not check the mail and a moment later heard Staff 6 calling
for assistance over the radio because Youth A hit her with a
weapon. Staff 5 reported she went outside to assist and
witnessed Youth A hit Staff 6 multiple times with two fiberglass
yardsticks used to mark the driveway. Staff 5 stated she
10

attempted to place Youth A in an upper torso restraint, but Youth
A got out of the restraint. Staff 5 reported Youth A threated to hit
Staff 5 with the yardsticks and that is when Staff 6 called 911 on
her personal cell phone. Staff 5 described telling Staff 6 there
were protocols in place to call 911 and they [staff] needed upper
management’s permission.
Staff 5 reported Staff 3 arrived to assist and switched places with
Staff 5 and Staff 5 returned to the house with the remaining youth.
Staff 5 stated from inside the house she watched out the window
and saw Youth A standing in the road and then sit in the road.
Staff 5 described seeing Youth B and Youth C trying to pull Youth
A out of the road. Staff 5 reported MSP arrived and transported
Y outh A to the hospital.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 3,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 6 described
Youth A being upset and going outside to check the mail. Staff 6
stated she told Youth A she could not check the mail which
caused Youth A to further escalate. Staff 6 reported Youth A
grabbed the fiberglass yardsticks from the driveway and hit Staff 6
multiple times. Staff 6 described Staff 5 coming from the house to
assist. Staff 6 stated she called 911 as soon as Youth A started
hitting her with the yardsticks because Youth A was assaulting
her. Staff 6 reported Staff 3 came outside to assist and told Staff
6 she should not have contacted 911.
Staff 6 stated when Staff 5 came outside, Staff 5 attempted to
place Youth A into a restraint, but Youth A was able to get out of
the restraint. Staff 6 reported Youth A hit Staff 5 with the
yardsticks as well then walked into the road where there was
traffic. Staff 6 stated she attempted to guide Youth A by her elbow
out of the road, but Youth A refused to move out of the road and
ended up sitting down in the road. Staff 6 reported Youth B and
Youth C grabbed Youth A’s legs and dragged Youth A to the curb.
Staff 6 stated she told Youth B and Youth C they could not drag
Youth A and Staff 3, who had come outside to assist, said it was
okay they did that. Staff 6 stated MSP arrived and placed Youth A
in handcuffs and into the patrol car because Youth A attempted to
jump into traffic again.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report for Youth A dated 3/27/25. This report is
consistent with staff and youth interviews.
• New Hope Policy, Safe Crisis Management and Physical
Intervention. Policy states, “Safe Crisis Management
11

(SCM) is the verbal and physical intervention program
trained and used by program staff at all Youth Opportunity,
Michigan programs.” There is not an approved technique
for staff to carry youth.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews, no staff dragged Youth A, however Youth B and Youth
C moved Youth A out of the road, without being asked or told to
do so by staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
